School of Mechanical Engineering Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology Beijing 102617 China Methanol steam reforming (MSR) combined with simultaneous hydrogen purification using palladium membranes offers an advanced method for on-board hydrogen utilization in fuel cell vehicles. However, commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts typically operate around 300 °C, significantly lower than palladium membranes. In this study, a series of γ-Al2O3 supported and CeO2 and La2O3 modified low-copper catalysts (n%Cu-CL-Al, n% = 2∼6 wt.%) were synthesized and compared with a commercial 45 %Cu-Zn-Al catalyst at 1.1 MPa. The Cu-CL-Al catalysts exhibited higher hydrogen yields (Y [H2]) at temperatures above 400 °C. This performance is attributed to a limited reverse water-gas shift (R-WGS) reaction, facilitated by the strong CO2 absorption properties of rare earth oxides. During long-term stability tests, the activity of the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst significantly decreased after 50 h but rapidly recovered upon oxygen introduction. As no significant carbon deposition was observed on the catalyst surface, and nearly all Cu species in the used catalyst were reduced to Cu0, suggesting that deactivation was due to the over-reduction of Cu species by the generated H2. The presence of O2 accelerated the oxidation rate of Cu0, maintaining an appropriate Cu0/Cu+ ratio for MSR reaction. At 450 °C, Y [H2] was constrained only by the equilibrium of R-WGS reaction, independent of the Cu loading and contact time. This indicates that for on-board hydrogen production using Cu-based catalysts, it is crucial to regulate Cu loading and catalyst quantity to achieve Y [H2] that surpass the equilibrium limit of the chemical reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ce and la promotion Cu-Al catalyst Methanol steam reforming On-board hydrogen production Stability strategy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (FCVs) present a promising alternative for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, yet they encounter hydrogen storage and transportation safety and infrastructure challenges [1,2]. On-board hydrogen production from liquid raw materials may offer a more ideal solution [3].Methanol steam reforming (MSR, Eq.(1)) can be considered a suitable method for on-board hydrogen supply due to its relatively low reaction temperature (250–300 °C) and the ease of methanol transportation and storage [4,5]. Low-temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells (LT-PEMFCs), widely used in vehicles, require hydrogen from MSR to be purified to over 99.97 % (ISO 14,687) [6]. A membrane reactor is considered promising for on-board hydrogen production, as it enables the coupling of reforming and purification in a compact volume with high energy efficiency [7]. Hydrogen purification using a Pd membrane typically requires temperatures exceeding 400 °C and pressures greater than 1.0 MPa, resulting in a temperature differential of over 100 °C compared to the MSR reaction [8]. Additionally, high pressures hinder the reforming process due to its volume expansion nature. Therefore, a catalyst that is efficient under both reforming and purification conditions is essential. Catalysts used for MSR to produce hydrogen typically include copper [9], nickel [10], and noble metals [11] as active components. Among these, copper-based catalysts are preferred by many researchers due to their superior low-temperature selectivity and cost-effectiveness [12]. γ-Al2O3 is commonly used as a support for reforming catalysts because it enhances the specific surface area and improves anti-sintering properties [13]. The promoting effect of Ce and La on CuO/Al2O3 catalysts has been evaluated in CO oxidation [14], ethanol CO2 reforming [15], and water-gas shift [16] reactions. The introduction of CeO2 and La2O3 can inhibit coke deposition, enhance oxygen storage capacity, and strengthen the interaction between active species and the support [17]. We hypothesize that copper-based catalysts supported on alumina modified with rare earth oxides (denoted as Cu-CL-Al, where CL represents CeO2 and La2O3) have the potential to serve as effective MSR catalysts. The MSR process, widely employed for hydrogen production, has demonstrated significant success with commercial catalysts such as CuO-ZnO-Al2O3 (Cu-Zn-Al). High copper loading (e.g., 45 %) facilitates excellent low-temperature activity but is no longer the primary focus of catalyst development for on-board hydrogen production. The MSR reaction includes methanol decomposition (MD, Eq. (2)), the water-gas shift (WGS, Eq. (3)), and methanation (Eq. (4)), among others [18]. Reducing Cu loading to increase the MD reaction temperature and incorporating CeO2 and La2O3 to regulate oxidation–reduction reactions like WGS is anticipated to develop more suitable catalysts for on-board use than the commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts. For the methanol oxidation steam reforming (OSR, Eq. (5)) reaction, the external energy demand (EED) can be precisely controlled by adjusting the O2/methanol molar ratio [19]. Reducing the overall EED of the membrane reactor is advantageous for aligning it with the energy system of FCVs and enhancing its applicability. (1) C H 3 OH + H 2 O ↔ 3 H 2 + C O 2 , Δ H 298 0 = 49.5 kJ / mol (2) C H 3 OH ↔ r MD 2 H 2 + CO , Δ H 298 0 = 90.2 kJ / mol (3) CO + H 2 O ↔ r WGS H 2 + C O 2 , Δ H 298 0 = − 41.2 kJ / mol (4) CO + 3 H 2 ↔ r methanation C H 4 + H 2 O , Δ H 298 0 = − 206 kJ / mol (5) C H 3 OH + ( 1 − n ) H 2 O + 0.5 n O 2 ↔ ( 3 − n ) H 2 + C O 2 , Δ H 298 0 = 49.5 − 241.8 n kJ / mol In this study, a series of Cu-CL-Al catalysts with low Cu loading were prepared and compared to a commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalyst. The regulatory mechanism of the CL-modified catalyst on the WGS reaction was also discussed. The reaction conditions were maintained at approximately 400 °C and 1.1 MPa to align with the operating conditions for Pd membrane. Additionally, the EED for the expected reactor was calculated. Various characterization techniques were employed to analyze the catalysts before and after the reaction, and the influence of oxygen in the MSR reaction was also considered. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Cu-CL-Al catalysts with Cu loadings ranging from 2 to 6 wt.% were synthesized using the impregnation method. Cerium (III) nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, AR grade, MACKLIN) and lanthanum (III) nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O, AR grade, MACKLIN) were mixed in a 2:1 molar ratio to prepare a 2 mol/L rare earth salt solution. Copper (II) nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, AR grade, MACKLIN) was also prepared as a 2 mol/L solution. Three 10 mL aliquots of the rare earth salt solution were taken, and 5 mL, 10 mL, and 15 mL of copper nitrate solution were added respectively to prepare three mixed solutions with varying Cu contents. Subsequently, 24 g of γ-Al2O3 (20–22 mesh, surface area ≈ 210 m2/g) was added, followed by stirring for 15 min. The precursors were then dried at 110 °C for 6 h and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h Additionally, the commercial columnar Cu-Zn-Al catalyst was crushed into 20–22 mesh particles for comparison. 2.2 Catalytic performance tests The MSR reaction was conducted in a stainless steel tubular reactor with a 10 mm diameter. Methanol (>99.99 %, AR grade, MACKLIN), diluted with deionized water, achieved a steam to methanol (carbon) molar ratio (S/C) between 1 and 1.5 upon vaporization. N2 was infused at 30 mL/min to maintain a system pressure of 1.1 MPa. Using 2.4 g of catalyst, preheated to above 200 °C, the vaporized methanol and steam were introduced. The methanol flow rate to catalyst weight ratio (F/W) ranged from 7.5 to 22.5 μ mol · s − 1 · g cata − 1 . Tests were conducted between 250 °C and 450 °C. Products were analyzed using gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 8890) equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors (TCD) and one flame ionization detector (FID). Detection limits were 100 ppm for H2, CO, CO2, and 0.5 ppm for CH4 and organic compounds. Each temperature point was stabilized for 100 min, and 5 measurements were taken. To comply with safety requirements, the catalyst stability test was conducted intermittently. Each cycle consisted of a 10-hour continuous run at 400 °C, with S/C and F/W ratios of 1.25 mol/mol and 7.5 μ mol · s − 1 · g cata − 1 , respectively. Subsequently, the supply of methanol and steam was halted, and the catalyst bed was cooled to room temperature under continuous N2 purging for 12 h After completing five cycles, oxygen was introduced using air as the source, maintaining an oxygen to methanol molar ratio (O/C) of 0.05 mol/mol, while simultaneously replacing an equivalent volume of N2. Since this study was conducted under online conditions with an operating pressure of 1.1 Mpa, a normal flow rate at room temperature ( F [ m ] ) was considered to account for the volume change resulting from the reactions. (6) F [ m ] ( μ mol / s ) = C [ m ] × F [ N 2 ] C [ N 2 ] where F [ N 2 ] is the N2 flow rate under a room temperature, C [ N 2 ] is the concentration of N2 (%), and C [ m ] is the concentration value of product m (%) detected by GC. The conversion was calculated using the following formula: (7) X [ m ] ( % ) = F [ m ] in − F [ m ] out F [ m ] in For methanol, F [ m ] in and F [ m ] out represent the normal flow rate measured at the reactor inlet and outlet, respectively. For the products, F [ m ] in obtained the theoretical calculation value based on the aforementioned reaction equation. The selectivity of the C1 products (CO2, CO and CH4) can be approximated as follows: (8) S [ m ] ( % ) = F [ m ] out F [ C H 3 OH ] in The hydrogen yield is defined by the following formula: (9) Y [ H 2 ] ( mol / mol ) = F [ H 2 ] out F [ C H 3 OH ] in After the complete decomposition of methanol ( X [ C H 3 OH ] = 1 ), and without considering the methane reaction (Eq. (4)), the equilibrium concentrations of H2, H2O, CO, and CO2 are determined by the WGS reaction. The equilibrium constant (K p) for the WGS reaction can be expressed as: (10) K p = X [ CO ] × ( X [ CO ] + 2 ) ( 1 − X [ CO ] ) × ( S / C − X [ CO ] ) As the correlation between the equilibrium constant and the reaction temperature has already been established by previous researchers (Eq. (11)) [20], the theoretical conversion X [CO] at a specific temperature under MSR reaction conditions can be calculated. (11) K p = exp ( 4577.8 T − 4.33 ) In addition, when the S/C ratio surpasses the stoichiometric level, the Y [ H 2 ] calculation can be performed as follows: (12) Y [ H 2 ] = 2 + X [ CO ] − 2 × O / C As the reaction temperature exceeds the commonly reported range, the production of organic compounds becomes minimal. The carbon balance is calculated to be 100 ± 3 % (with N2 as an internal reference) based on the input of methanol and the output of CO, CO2, and CH4, as detailed below: (13) Carbon Balance ( % ) = F [ C O 2 ] out + F [ CO ] out + F [ C H 4 ] out F [ C H 3 OH ] in × 100 % Based on formulas (9) and (12), the relationship between the measured and calculated values of Y [ H 2 ] can be established. The hydrogen balance is calculated to be 100 ± 3 % using the following formula: (14) Hydrogen Balance ( % ) = 2 + X [ CO ] − 2 × O / C F [ H 2 ] out / F [ C H 3 OH ] in × 100 % 2.3 Catalysts characterization The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were measured via N2 physisorption at −196 °C using a Quantachrome Quadrasorb S1. Prior to measurement, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 200 °C for 3 h. The BET equation was employed to calculate the specific surface area, while the BJH method was utilized to determined pore size distribution. XRD patterns were obtained using a Rigaku SmartLab 9 kW diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Data was collected for 2θ ranging from 5° to 90° with a step size of 0.02° The average particle size of Cu-CL-Al samples was estimated using Scherrer equation. Catalyst compositions were quantitatively analyzed via ICP-OES using an Agilent 5800 device. The oxidation state and surface composition of the catalysts were analyzed via X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), recorded on a scanning X-ray microprobe (Nexsa X, ThermoFisher) employing Al Kα radiation. Binding energies were calibrated against the C 1 s level (BE = 284.8 eV) as the standard reference. To qualitatively assess the microstructural characteristics and elemental composition on the surface of the samples, a scanning electron microscope (SEM), specifically the JEOL 700 model from Japan, equipped with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS), was utilized. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were conducted using a chemisorption analyzer (BEL-CAT-II) to evaluate the reducibility of the material at different temperatures. A sample weighing 640 mg was heated from room temperature to 750 °C in a reducing gas mixture (5.0 vol.% H2/Ar, 50 mL/min) with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. The NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) behavior of the catalysts was examined using the same equipment. Initially, the sample was heated to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under a helium flow of 50 mL/min. After an isothermal treatment at 500 °C for 30 min, the sample was cooled to 50 °C and then exposed to 5 % NH3 in helium (50 mL/min) for an additional 90 min. The TPD experiment was subsequently conducted under a helium flow (50 mL/min) while increasing the temperature from 50 °C to 750 °C. In the Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) process, potassium bromide was loaded into the sample cell with nitrogen gas flowed at a rate of 50 mL/min. Once the system stabilized, background spectra were captured. Subsequently, a 1:1 mixture of catalyst and potassium bromide was placed in the cell, again with nitrogen gas flowing at 50 mL/min. Spectra were continuously recorded until stability was achieved, with background subtraction applied for analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The comparative catalytic performance of the synthesized Cu-CL-Al catalysts and the commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalyst for the MSR reaction is illustrated in Fig. 1 . It is evident that a decrease in Cu loading results in an increase in the complete conversion temperature of methanol (Fig. 1A). At 350 °C, the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst achieved the highest Y [H2] as depicted in Fig. 1B. When the temperature reached 450 °C, Y [H2] became independent of Cu loading. For the Cu-CL-Al catalysts, the S [CO] was zero (with CO undetected) at 250 °C, signifying that the WGS reaction had reached equilibrium. Further heating resulted in a predominance of the reverse water-gas shift (R-WGS) reaction (Fig. 1C). The superior CO inhibition capacity of the Cu-CL-Al catalysts demonstrates their potential for low-temperature MSR reaction, which will be addressed in future studies. Although the S [CH4] for all investigated catalysts increased with temperature, it remained below 0.4 % (Fig. 1D). Furthermore, no significant organic by-products were observed, indicating that S [CO2] was approximately equal to 1 - S [CO]. Therefore, it is reasonable to focus on the effect of the R-WGS reaction on Y [H2] in the subsequent discussion. Fig. 2 presents the X [CO] and apparent activation energy (Ea, fitting results available in Supplementary Material Fig. S1) for the Cu-CL-Al and Cu-Zn-CL catalysts. When the temperature exceeds 300 °C, the X [CO] of the Cu-Zn-CL catalyst closely aligns with the calculated values from formulas (9) and (12), as methanol nearly achieves complete conversion (Fig. 2A). In contrast, although X [CH3OH] exceeds 99 % at 350 °C, the X [CO] of the Cu-CL-Al catalyst significantly deviates from the calculated value, indicating restricted R-WGS activity. As shown in Fig. 2B, the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst demonstrates the highest R-WGS Ea, which explains the higher Y [H2] compared to other catalysts above 350 °C. The effects of F/W and S/C ratios on the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 . As F/W increases, Y [H2] (Fig. 3A) decreases significantly due to the lower X [CH3OH] (Fig. S2) in the temperature range of 250 - 350 °C. However, increasing F/W benefits CO2 selectivity improvement, as both S [CO] (Fig. S3) and S [CH4] (Fig. S4) decrease. Within the range of 7.5 to 22.5 μ mol · s − 1 · g cata − 1 , X [CO] (Fig. S5) decreased from 100 % to the theoretical predictions, further confirming the excellent regulatory capability of the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst in WGS and R-WGS reactions. At 450 °C and F/W below 15 μ mol · s − 1 · g cata − 1 , Y [H2] is determined solely by WGS equilibrium and is independent of the type or amount of catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 3b, the Y [H2] of the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst increases with the S/C ratio. Notably, Y [H2] significantly exceeded theoretical predictions at an S/C ratio of 1.25 mol/mol. 3.2 External energy demand In order to achieve good energy efficiency for H2 produced on-board, the external energy demand (EED) of the H2 production unit must be minimized. This demand can be determined by employing the following formula: (15) Q e = Q g + Q up + Q MD + Q R − WGS − Q s − Q cool Qe, external energy demand of the hydrogen production unit; Qg, heat required for methanol and water vaporization; Qup, energy required for reactant heating to the operating temperature; QMD, heat absorbed during methanol decomposition; QR-WGS, heat absorbed during the reverse water-gas shift reaction; Qs, heat recovered from energy molecules in the retained gas after hydrogen separation; Qcool, heat released during the cooling of product pure hydrogen and retained gas. As Qup and Qcool can be effectively offset through heat exchange devices, their effects can be neglected. Assuming a hydrogen recovery rate (η, defined as the molar ratio of pure hydrogen to reforming hydrogen) of 90 % for the Pd membrane, the EED under various S/C conditions can be roughly estimated (Fig. 4 ). EED reached zero with an S/C ratio of 1.2 to 1.3 mol/mol and a temperature range of 400 to 500 °C, calculated based on the WGS equilibrium. In a Pd membrane reactor, the timely separation of H2 shifts the equilibrium toward H2 production. For the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst, the X [CO] exceeded theoretical predictions. These factors collectively increase the S/C ratio at a certain temperature to achieve zero EED. For the subsequent stability test, an S/C ratio of 1.25 mol/mol at 400 °C is used to align with the operating conditions of the Pd membrane and to minimize the EED of the H2 production unit. 3.3 Stability analysis At 400 °C, the 4 % Cu-CL-Al catalyst maintained a stable X [CH3OH] and showed a slight increase in Y [H2] within the initial 10 h (Fig. 5 ). During the second cycle, both X [CH3OH] and Y [H2] exhibited a substantial decline. After five operation cycles, X [CH3OH] was reduced to 60 %, and Y [H2] decreased to 1.7 mol/mol. It has been widely reported that Cu-based catalysts are prone to deactivation when the temperature exceeds 300 °C [20]. Traditional methods for preventing deactivation, such as lowering the reaction temperature and enhancing the low-temperature activity of catalysts, are insufficient to meet the operational conditions of Pd membranes. Upon introducing air into the system, the activity of the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst rapidly recovered within one hour. This indicates that the stability of the catalyst can be effectively maintained by introducing trace amounts of O2, given that the O/C ratio is only 0.05. The used 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst was analyzed using the TG-DSC method, as shown in Fig. 6 . The catalyst experienced a weight loss of <5 %, and minor peaks around 170–300 °C in the DSC curve, which are attributed to low molecular weight organic compounds deposited on the catalyst surface [10]. This confirms the thermal stability of the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst, indicating that its deactivation under MSR conditions is not due to coke deposition. 3.4 Physical and chemical properties This section examines the effects of copper loading, the changes observed before and after using the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst, and the promotional mechanism of oxygen in the MSR reaction. ICP results indicate a stable total loading of Ce and La at 10.6 ± 0.3 wt.%. The molar ratio of La to (Ce+La) is 0.329 ± 0.003, closely matching the target ratio of 1/3. Thus, the primary compositional difference among the Cu-CL-Al catalysts is the Cu content. The N2 adsorption-desorption analysis reveals that all four catalysts exhibit type-IV isotherms with typical H3 hysteresis loops, as depicted in Fig. 7 A. The used 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst demonstrates a significant decrease in the steepness of the isotherm curve and a narrowing of the hysteresis loop, suggesting some degradation of its ordered pore structure [21]. In Fig. 7B, the fresh catalyst shows broad peaks in the pore size distribution, while the used catalyst exhibits a slight shift of this peak towards larger sizes. The specific surface area decreases linearly with increasing Cu loading in the fresh catalysts due to the progressive stacking of CuO particles [22], while the used catalyst exhibits a significant decrease (Fig. 7C). There is a slight increase in pore volume of the used catalyst compared to the fresh one (Fig. 7D). The CeO2 crystallite size in the used catalyst remains at 6–7 nm with no obvious aggregation, as calculated using the Scherrer formula from XRD results.These observations indicate that after long-term use, smaller pores in the γ-Al2O3 support merge into larger ones, rather than the supported oxides undergoing sintering. The XRD patterns of all four samples exhibit fluorite-type cubic structure (JCPDS 34–0934) of CeO2, with peaks almost entirely obscuring the diffraction peaks of the Al2O3 support, indicating the well-dispersion of CeO2 (Fig. 8 ). The peak position corresponding to the (111) plane of the fresh catalyst remains stable at 28.60±0.01, consistent with pure CeO2 (see Fig. S6 for details), indicting no formation of a Ce-based solid solution [23] As the Cu loading increases, two weak peaks characteristic of the CuO phase (JCPDS 45–0937) in the 6 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst at 35.5° and 38.8° suggest the presence of bulk CuO crystallites. A diffraction peak of Cu0 (JCPDS 04–0836) observed in the used catalyst is attributed to the reduction of Cu species to metallic Cu by H2 generated during the MSR reaction. It has been reported that when La loadings are below 8.5 mol/m2, a 2-dimensional overlayer forms on Al2O3, which is not detectable by XRD [3]. It is believed that Cu and La do not doped into the CeO2 lattice but are highly dispersed. XPS characterization was performed to obtain surface structural and composition information of fresh and used Cu-CL-Al catalysts (see Fig. S7 for the full spectrum). The C1 s XPS spectrum exhibited a main peak centered at 284.8 eV (excluding the shift, Fig. S8), and two additional peaks at 286.6 ± 0.1 eV and 288.9 ± 0.1 eV corresponding to CO and C = O, respectively. This indicates the adsorption of CO2 on CeO2 and La2O3, leading to the formation of CO3 2- species [24–25]. For the fresh Cu-CL-Al catalyst, two major peaks are observed at 934.5 ± 0.1 eV and 954.6 ± 0.2 eV, with satellite peaks in the ranges of 932–948 eV and 960–966 eV (Fig. 9 A), attributed to the presence of Cu²⁺ in crystalline CuO [26]. For the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst, new peaks with lower binding energies emerged at 932.7 eV and 952.5 eV, indicating the presence of Cu+ [27]. The calculated ratio of Cu+/(Cu++Cu2+) reached up to 73 %, indicating strong interactions between Cu species and other substances, which partially reduced Cu2+ to Cu+ by sharing electrons. The used 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst exhibited peaks at 931.9 eV and 951.8 eV, which are significantly lower than the binding energies of Cu+. These peaks are therefore attributed to metallic Cu (Cu0) [28]. This observation is consistent with the XRD characterization results, indicating that Cu+ and Cu2+ are almost entirely reduced to Cu0 by the generated H2. In the analysis of the O 1 s XPS spectra of the samples as shown in Fig. 9B, the peak observed at a binding energy of 529.9 ± 0.2 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (OL). Additionally, the peak at 531.2 ± 0.1 eV corresponds to surface oxygen (OS), which is related to oxygen vacancies (OV) [29,30]. As evidenced by the C1 s and La 3d spectra, the formation of carbonates and hydroxyl groups on all catalysts is confirmed. Consequently, the peak located at 532.8 ± 0.1 eV is associated with adsorbed CO3 2-/OH- species (OA), which is consistent with previous reports [31]. These species serve as oxidation sites, facilitating the adsorption and dissociation of CO2 and H2O on the surface of Cu-CL-Al catalysts. The OS/O and Ce3+/Ce ratios, derived from the O1 s and Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. S9) [32,33], are presented in Fig. 9C. For the fresh catalysts, a clear correlation is observed between the OS/O and Ce3+/Ce ratios. Notably, the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst demonstrates higher concentrations of Cu+, Ce3+, and OV, suggesting a strong interaction between Cu and Ce oxides that facilitates the formation of additional OV (Eq. (16)). (16) C u 2 + − O − C e 4 + ↔ − 2 e C u + − O − C e 3 + + O v The excellent WGS activity of Cu-Ce catalysts is widely reported, and this advantage is also evident in the ethanol reforming reaction [34]. Consequently, the higher Y [H2] observed in the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst can be attributed to the strong interaction between Cu and Ce oxides, which promotes the WGS reaction and prevents it from reaching equilibrium in the reverse direction. For the used catalysts, the OS/O and Ce3+/Ce ratios exhibit a significant increase, indicating the formation of additional OV during the MSR reaction [35]. Even in the final cycle of the stability experiment conducted under oxygen-containing conditions, the catalyst maintains a high surface oxygen content, with Cu and Ce species being reduced by the generated H2 (CuO0.6 CeO1.9 → Cu0-CeO1.8). For both fresh and used 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalysts, the La 3d spectra exhibit two main peaks centered at 836.0 ± 0.1 eV and 852.6 ± 0.1 eV, corresponding to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 levels of La3+, respectively (Fig. S10) [36]. While for the 2 %Cu-CL-Al and 6 %Cu-CL-Al catalysts, these two peaks increased by approximately 1.0 eV, which is related to the partial formation of La2O2CO3 [37]. For all four catalyst samples, the splitting between the main peak and the satellite peak is typical for La(OH)3 (△E = 3.5 eV), which is formed spontaneously from the reaction of lanthanum oxide with water vapor at room temperature [38]. As illustrated in Fig. 9D, the surface and bulk La contents are similar across all four catalysts, further confirming that La3+ is not doped into the CeO2 lattice to form a commonly reported solid solution, but is highly dispersed on the surface of the Al2O3 support. Cu forms a significant enrichment on the surface of the fresh catalyst, whereas the surface enrichment of Ce diminishes with increasing Cu loading, presumably due to coverage by Cu species. Based on the aforementioned characterization, it is tentatively proposed that a strong interaction exists between Cu species and Ce oxides within the Cu-CL-Al catalyst, while La is likely to be highly dispersed on the surface of the Al2O3 support. 3.5 Surface structure and redox properties The SEM images and EDX spectra of both fresh and used 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalysts are presented in Fig. 10 . For both the fresh (Fig. 10A) and used (Fig. 10G) catalysts, backscattered images reveal the presence of spherical particles with a size of approximately 0.5 μm on the surface of the Al2O3 support. The table in Fig. 10 compares the elemental composition results from the map sum and the average values of three particles (1–3 Ave and 4–6 Ave), indicating that the Cu and Ce contents in the particles are significantly higher than those in the map sum. Furthermore, the EDX spectra illustrate a consistent distribution of Cu and Ce species, further confirming the strong interaction between them. Furthermore, the EDX spectra illustrate a consistent distribution of Cu and Ce species, further confirming the strong interaction between them. The coexistence of Cu and Ce species, which can be reduced by the generated H2, does not significantly affect the microscopic morphology of the catalyst during the valence state transition of these species. For La, there is no significant difference observed between the map sum and the particles, and its distribution pattern suggests that it is highly dispersed within the catalyst. The highly dispersed La2O3 on the surface can cover the acidic sites of the Al2O3 support and readily interacts with CO2 to form La2O2CO3, which has been widely reported to enhance the catalyst's anti-coking performance [39]. Therefore, despite the catalyst experiencing significant deactivation during the MSR reaction, no substantial coke deposition is observed. This further confirms that the strong interaction between Cu and Ce species facilitated the formation of CuCeOx microspheres in the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst, with no significant microstructural changes observed after H2 reduction, while La species remained highly dispersed independently. The activity of the R-WGS reaction is reported to increase with the acidic nature of the catalyst [40]. Therefore, NH3-TPD experiments were conducted to identify the acidity of the catalyst. NH3-TPD experiments were conducted to identify the acidity of the catalyst. As commonly reported, acid sites can be classified into three types, labeled as α, β, and γ in Fig. 11 A, in ascending order of acidity strength [41]. The peak α around 110 °C is attributed to weak acid sites resulting from physisorbed NH3 on the surface and NH3 adsorbed onto weak Lewis acid sites [42]. The peak β observed around 300 °C is attributed to NH3 adsorbed onto strong Lewis acid sites, primarily created by metal ions (Cu, Ce, and La) [27]. This peak exhibited a slight decrease with increasing Cu loading, while it increased for the used catalyst due to the influence of Cu species. Peak γ above 630 °C is related to NH3 adsorbed onto Brønsted acid sites generated by framework hydroxyl group species, such as La(OH)3 and Al(OH)3 formed by the interaction of metallic oxide with water [43]. Among all four catalysts, the observed peak γ shows minimal differences due to the high dispersion of La species. The FTIR spectra presented in Fig. 11B, aim to further confirm the surface-absorbed functional groups of the catalysts. The peaks observed at approximately 1450 cm-1, 1600 cm-1 and 3500 cm-1 correspond to the vibrational frequency of the OH group for all four catalysts, arising from water absorption by the catalysts [28]. For the steam reforming reaction, acidic sites are generally believed to adsorb water and promote its dissociation into protons and surface hydroxyls [44]. In ceria-based materials, the coexistence of Ce3+ further favors H2O dissociation, with hydroxyls remaining on the surface above 230 °C during WGS reaction conditions [45]. According to NH3-TPD and FTIR characterization results, all four catalysts exhibit similar acidity and H2O adsorption and dissociation capabilities. Therefore, the high X [CO] observed for the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst is primarily due to its higher Ce3+ content, which reduces the rate of surface hydroxyl desorption, and hinders the R-WGS reaction. The band at 2350 cm-1 is related to the stretching frequency of the C=O bonds due to the adsorbed CO2 molecules from the atmosphere on the catalysts. The vibration of physically adsorbed carbonate bands was reported with characteristic peaks in the range of 1220 to 1520 cm-1 [46]. Therefore, the peaks centered at 1250 and 1390 cm-1 are attributed to carbonate species formed by adsorbed CO2 on the catalyst surface [47]. The peaks related to carbonate formation on the surface of the 2 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst are relatively weak, indicating that Cu species affect the adsorption of CO2 and the generation of carbonates. The H2-TPR method is used to determine the reducibility of Cu-CL-Al and commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts, in order to understand the differences in redox properties between them and the reason for the recovery of catalytic activity after introducing oxygen into the MSR reaction (Fig. 12 ). For the 2 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst, roughly three peaks were observed, while only a notably broadened peak was seen for the 4 %Cu-CL-Al and 6 %Cu-CL-Al catalysts . This behavior can be attributed to the electron-providing capacity of Ce and La ions, which enhances electron density on CuO particles and facilitates the H2 reduction process [15]. As the Cu loading increases, the reducibility of Cu-based catalysts extends towards lower temperatures, aligning with the observed trend in its MSR activity. It is widely reported that the activity of Cu-based catalysts rises with increasing with Cu loading [48]. The reduction of Cu in Cu-based catalysts typically proceeds through two steps: Cu2+ → Cu+ and Cu+ → Cu0 [22]. Both Cu0 and Cu+ are considered as active species for the MSR reaction, and the ratio of Cu0/Cu+ essentially controls the MSR activity behavior [49]. As reported, both CO and H2 can completely reduce Cu species to the metallic state (Cu0) [50]. The deactivation of the catalyst during the MSR reaction can be attributed to its inability to maintain an appropriate Cu0/Cu+ ratio, as Cu+/Cu2+ is nearly completely reduced to Cu0 by the generated H2. As Cu° can be oxidized to Cu+by CO2 and H2O, the presence of Cu species in the used catalyst as Cu0 suggests that the oxidation of Cu0 is the rate-controlling step in the entire redox process [50,51]. The rapid recovery of catalyst activity after O2 introduction is attributed to the stronger oxidizing capability of O2 compared to CO2 and H2O, which accelerates the oxidation of Cu0 and dynamically mitigates the deficiency of Cu+ on the catalyst surface. The stable performance of commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts can be attributed to their high copper loading, which complicates complete reduction and sustainably maintains an optimal Cu0/Cu+ ratio. 3.6 Design principles for on-board MSR catalysts Based on catalyst performance evaluation and characterization analysis, we believe that in the Cu-CL-Al catalyst, Al2O3 primarily serves to provide acidic sites that promote the adsorption and dissociation of H2O. The porous microsphere structure of Al2O3 enhances the specific surface area and increases the proportion of surface oxygen in the catalyst. In comparison to columnar commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts, the prepared Cu-CL-Al spherical catalyst is more convenient for packing into palladium membrane reactors. La2O3 is highly dispersed within the catalyst, serving as a crucial adsorption site for both H2O and CO2, and enhancing the overall resistance of the catalyst to carbon deposition. Cu-Zn-Al is an effective commercial catalyst for the MSR reaction, with Cu0 and Cu+ identified as the active sites. A notably high copper loading of 45 % helps maintain the activity of this catalyst; however, at elevated temperatures, such as 400 °C, the Y [H2] decreases due to the WGS equilibrium. To optimize the operating conditions of palladium membranes, precisely controlling the modification strategy for the WGS reaction is a more effective approach to enhancing Y [H2] than simply increasing the copper loading. For the fresh 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst, the strong interaction between CuO x and CeO2-δ favors the conversion of Cu2+-O-Ce4+ to Cu+-O-Ce3+ with the generation of OV. Additionally, in the MSR reaction, Cu+ is easily reduced to Cu0 by H2 and CO. Cu0 then provide electrons to adjacent CeO2, leading to the interconversion between Cu0-O-Ce4+ and Cu+-O-Ce3+ and generating more OV due to the weakening of interfacial Ce-O bonds [52]. The increase of OV and the formation of carbonate on the CeO2 surface are both unfavorable for the R-WGS reaction. When the MSR reaction temperature exceeds 350 °C, the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst becomes overqualified for both the MSR and WGS reactions. The focus of catalyst design shifts to reducing its R-WGS activity. Reports indicate that adding Ce and La to Cu-Al catalysts shifts the reduction peak of the H2-TPR curve towards higher temperatures, accompanied by an increase in area [15]. This indicates that an increase in CL loading can further diminish the R-WGS activity, attributed to the broader redox range and lower efficiency displayed by Cu-CL-Al catalysts. The introduction of O2 is beneficial for dynamically maintaining an optimal Cu0/Cu+ ratio at high temperature, enabling the catalyst to maintain high stability and adapt to on-board hydrogen production. Furthermore, while ensuring nearly complete methanol conversion, reducing the catalyst dosage is favorable for suppressing the formation of CO and CH4 byproducts, which is advantageous for enhancing H2 separation efficiency and decreasing the volume of the palladium membrane reforming reactor. 4 Conclusion Producing pure hydrogen on-board using a palladium membrane reforming reactor is increasingly recognized as an ideal method for hydrogen utilization in FCVs. This approach mitigates the safety risks and cost issues associated with hydrogen storage and transportation. However, the operating temperature required for palladium membranes is typically at least 100 °C higher than that needed for the MSR reaction. Lowering the operating temperature reduces the hydrogen separation efficiency of palladium membranes and exacerbates hydrogen embrittlement. Therefore, designing a suitable catalyst for the MSR reaction under the operating conditions of palladium membranes is a more feasible strategy for the development of palladium membrane reforming reactors. This study investigates the performance of a commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalyst, which exhibits excellent low-temperature activity and stability due to its high Cu loading of 45 %. However, as methanol conversion approaches completion at temperatures exceeding 300 °C, the Y [H2] aligns with the WGS reaction equilibrium, which decreases with increasing temperature. In contrast, the synthesized 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst achieves higher Y [H2] at 400 °C and 1.1 MPa, surpassing the WGS reaction equilibrium limitation. This indicates that this catalyst is a more suitable option for palladium membrane reforming reactors for the on-board production of pure hydrogen. The characterization results obtained from XRD, XPS, and SEM-EDX indicate that La2O3 is highly dispersed within the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst. The strong interaction between Cu species and CeO2 generates more oxygen vacancies compared to those observed in the 2 %Cu-CL-Al and 6 %Cu-CL-Al catalysts, leading to an increased activation energy for the R-WGS reaction and a higher Y [H2]. Analyses using XPS, NH3-TPD, and FTIR suggest that CeO2 and La2O3 function as effective CO2 adsorption sites, thereby inhibiting the R-WGS reaction. In contrast, both rare earth oxides and Al2O3 facilitate the adsorption and dissociation of H2O, promoting the WGS reaction, with CO remaining undetectable at 250 °C. Unlike the Cu-Zn-CL catalyst, which easily reaches WGS reaction equilibrium, the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst demonstrates a clear preference for the WGS reaction while inhibiting the R-WGS reaction during the MSR reaction. The XRD, XPS, and H2-TPR results confirm that the Cu species can be completely reduced to Cu0 by the generated H2. Since both Cu0 and Cu+ serve as active sites for the MSR reaction, excessive reduction of Cu species during long-term stability tests results in the deactivation of the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst. However, the activity can be rapidly restored by introducing oxygen, which maintains an appropriate Cu0/Cu+ ratio. Considering the real-time hydrogen separation facilitated by the palladium membrane, the reaction equilibrium will shift to favor H2 production. Therefore, the actual performance of palladium membrane reforming reactors requires further examination in future studies to meet the on-board H2 production requirements. Appendix A. coredata.dc:description: Methanol steam reforming (MSR) combined with simultaneous hydrogen purification using palladium membranes offers an advanced method for on-board hydrogen utilization in fuel cell vehicles. However, commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts typically operate around 300 °C, significantly lower than palladium membranes. In this study, a series of γ-Al2O3 supported and CeO2 and La2O3 modified low-copper catalysts (n%Cu-CL-Al, n% = 2∼6 wt.%) were synthesized and compared with a commercial 45 %Cu-Zn-Al catalyst at 1.1 MPa. The Cu-CL-Al catalysts exhibited higher hydrogen yields (Y [H2]) at temperatures above 400 °C. This performance is attributed to a limited reverse water-gas shift (R-WGS) reaction, facilitated by the strong CO2 absorption properties of rare earth oxides. During long-term stability tests, the activity of the 4 %Cu-CL-Al catalyst significantly decreased after 50 h but rapidly recovered upon oxygen introduction. As no significant carbon deposition was observed on the catalyst surface, and nearly all Cu species in the used catalyst were reduced to Cu0, suggesting that deactivation was due to the over-reduction of Cu species by the generated H2. The presence of O2 accelerated the oxidation rate of Cu0, maintaining an appropriate Cu0/Cu+ ratio for MSR reaction. At 450 °C, Y [H2] was constrained only by the equilibrium of R-WGS reaction, independent of the Cu loading and contact time. This indicates that for on-board hydrogen production using Cu-based catalysts, it is crucial to regulate Cu loading and catalyst quantity to achieve Y [H2] that surpass the equilibrium limit of the chemical reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Methanol steam reforming using Ce and La modified low-Cu catalysts for On-board hydrogen production
